definitions.definition: To allow to enter ; to grant entrance (to), whether into a place, into the mind, or into consideration
examples: to admit a serious thought into the mind
to admit evidence in the trial of a cause
A ticket admits one into a playhouse.
They were admitted into his house.

definitions.definition: To allow (someone) to enter a profession or to enjoy a privilege; to recognize as qualified for a franchise .
examples: to admit an attorney to practice law
The prisoner was admitted to bail.

definitions.definition: To concede as true ; to acknowledge or assent to, as an allegation which it is impossible to deny (+ to ).
examples: the argument or fact is admitted
She admitted taking drugs / she admitted to taking drugs.

definitions.definition: To be capable of; to permit . In this sense, "of" may be used after the verb, or may be omitted.
examples: The words do not admit such a construction.

definitions.definition: To give warrant or allowance , to grant opportunity or permission.
examples: Circumstances do not admit of this.
The text does not admit of this interpretation.

definitions.definition: To allow to enter a hospital or similar facility for treatment .

main_definition: ( transitive ) To allow to enter ; to grant entrance (to), whether into a place, into the mind, or into consideration
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To allow (someone) to enter a profession or to enjoy a privilege; to recognize as qualified for a franchise .
( transitive or intransitive ) To concede as true ; to acknowledge or assent to, as an allegation which it is impossible to deny (+ to ).
( transitive ) To be capable of; to permit . In this sense, "of" may be used after the verb, or may be omitted.
( intransitive , with of ) To give warrant or allowance , to grant opportunity or permission.
( transitive ) To allow to enter a hospital or similar facility for treatment .
